title: Week 3: January 12–18 - Genesis 1–2; Moses 2–3; Abraham 4–5
content:
# Come, Follow Me 2026: Week 3 - Genesis 1–2; Moses 2–3; Abraham 4–5

## Theological Framework

Imagine standing amid the unformed void of Genesis 1:2 and Abraham 4:2, where the earth lay “without form, and void” and “empty and desolate.” What divine pattern emerges as light pierces darkness, order triumphs chaos, and life fills emptiness? This Creation narrative unveils a theological framework of transformation: God, through His Only Begotten, crafts magnificence from disarray (Genesis 1:1–25; Moses 2:1–25; Abraham 4:1–25). This pattern repeats across dispensations—from the earth's formation to the personal renewal promised in Doctrine and Covenants 101:32–34, where “the light shall break forth among them” even in desolation.

Pattern Recognition Mastery reveals identical principles: Heavenly Father and Jesus Christ as master Creators, directing premortal intelligences in Abraham 4–5 much as They guide our mortal progression. In Genesis 1:26–27; Moses 2:26–27; Abraham 4:26–27, humanity emerges “in the image of God,” male and female, echoing eternal potential from premortal councils to exaltation. Marriage, ordained as man and woman unite (Genesis 1:27–28; 2:18–25; Moses 3:18, 21–24; Abraham 5:14–18), mirrors celestial unions, with stewardship over creations (Genesis 1:28; Moses 2:28; Abraham 4:28) extending to Sabbath sanctification (Genesis 2:2–3; Moses 3:2–3; Abraham 5:2–3). This framework declares: “By mine Only Begotten I created these things,” transforming chaos into divine order, personally and cosmically.

## Language and Literary Insights

The three accounts—Genesis 1–2, Moses 2–3, Abraham 4–5—form a literary triad, each illuminating the Creator's voice. Notice the repetitive divine declarations: “And God said, Let there be...” (Genesis 1), paralleling “the Gods organized and formed” in Abraham 4, suggesting collaborative councils among divine beings. This structure builds rhythmically, day by day, culminating in humanity's image-bearing role.

A paradigm shift arises in the nuanced phrasing of human creation: “in the image of God... male and female created he them” (Genesis 1:27; Moses 2:27; Abraham 4:27). The Hebrew-informed Bible Dictionary entry on “Genesis” underscores this as foundational narrative poetry, where “likeness” evokes resemblance to divine parents. The Garden accounts in Genesis 2:18–25 and Moses 3:18, 21–24 employ intimate relational language—“help meet,” “one flesh”—elevating marriage beyond utility. These literary echoes invite reverence, as pondering them outdoors amid “God’s creations” deepens the majestic prose's impact.

## Prophetic Patterns Across Time

Divine patterns of revelation pulse through Creation: from Elohim's plural “Gods” organizing in Abraham 4:1 (“the Gods, organized and formed the heavens and the earth”), foreshadowing council-driven covenants in Moses 2, to Genesis 1's singular Creator voice. This converges in redemption—light from void mirrors Christ's piercing mortal darkness, as stewardship commands (Genesis 1:28) echo across dispensations.

Covenant-making patterns shine: humanity's dominion mandate (Moses 2:28) parallels Adam and Eve's eternal marriage “by the power of [the] everlasting priesthood” (Russell M. Nelson, “Lessons from Eve,” Ensign, Nov. 1987, 87). Sabbath rest (Abraham 5:2–3) foreshadows millennial peace, linking ancient ordinances to latter-day renewal. Multiple Perspective Convergence reveals the same truth: Creation as Christ's handiwork, from premortal planning to our sanctification.

Hidden connections abound: “Image of God” counters natural man (Mosiah 3:19), weaving humility into divine potential (Ether 12:27). Stewardship links D&C 59:16–21's gratitude to Genesis 1:28's care.

## Historical and Cultural Context

In an ancient Near Eastern world of chaotic cosmologies, these accounts declare ordered purpose: from “without form, and void” (Genesis 1:2) to teeming life. The Garden of Eden depiction (as in Grant Romney Clawson's painting) evokes paradisiacal unity, where Adam and Eve's union (Moses 3:21–24) models eternal families amid cultural polygamy norms.

Aha moments emerge: stewardship (Abraham 4:28) counters exploitation, paralleling modern discipleship. Sabbath sanctification (Genesis 2:2–3) distinguished Israel from labor-obsessed neighbors, fostering worship. Pioneers echoed this, transforming deserts into gardens, as today's disciples cultivate personal Edens.

## Reconciling Difficult Passages

Apparent tensions between accounts resolve profoundly: Genesis 1's sequential days versus Abraham 4's “Gods” organizing premortal matter reveal complementary views—linear for mortals, council for eternals. “Male and female” simultaneity (Moses 2:27) versus Genesis 2's rib narrative harmonizes as poetic etiology emphasizing unity.

Some misread “image of God” as excusing flaws; yet Mosiah 3:19 and Ether 12:27 clarify: divine potential demands subduing the natural man. This pattern indicates progression from creation to perfection.

## Deeper Study Notes

Advanced insights from pattern discovery: Compare day-night parallels (Genesis 1) to spiritual light in chaos (D&C 101:32–34). Seminary adaptation: Map Creation days to personal attributes—light as truth, firmament as division from worldliness. Note Abraham 5's eternities: “intelligences that were organized before the world” prefigure our spirits. Teachers, trace stewardship from Eden to D&C 104:13–18 for covenant accountability.

## Teaching Applications

**Escalating Stakes Discussion Questions:**

1. **Understanding**: What patterns in Genesis 1:1–25; Moses 2:1–25; Abraham 4:1–25 teach about Christ's role? How does “empty and desolate” (Abraham 4:2) mirror personal trials?

2. **Transformation**: Ponder Genesis 1:26–27: “Because I know I am created in God’s image, I choose to…” How does this shift self-view? Role-play Sabbath explanations using Moses 3:2–3.

3. **Testimony**: How does eternal marriage (Genesis 2:18–25) converge with “The Family: A Proclamation to the World”? What Creation evidence builds conviction in Heavenly Father?

For children: Hunt creations outside, sing “My Heavenly Father Loves Me” (Children’s Songbook, 228–29), puzzle bodies to honor sacredness.

## Modern Prophetic Convergence

Contemporary voices mirror ancient truths verbatim. President Russell M. Nelson testifies in “God’s Greatest Creation” (Gospel Library): the human body as miraculous, countering worldly messages. He affirms, “Adam and Eve were joined together in marriage for time and for all eternity by the power of [the] everlasting priesthood” (Russell M. Nelson, “Lessons from Eve,” Ensign, Nov. 1987, 87). Elder Gérald Caussé echoes stewardship: “Our Earthly Stewardship,” Liahona, Nov. 2022, 57–59. President Nelson's “Your Body: A Magnificent Gift to Cherish,” Liahona, Aug. 2019, 50–55, converges precisely with Genesis 1:26–27.

## Testimony Development

Deep study of these patterns forges unshakeable conviction: Seeing Christ organize chaos personally assures His power in our voids. Knowing we bear God's image ignites divine worth; eternal marriage patterns testify of families forever. As I trace from Abraham's councils to today's prophets, my heart burns: Heavenly Father and Jesus Christ are indeed our Creators, guiding us to exaltation.

## Additional Study

Explore “The Sabbath Is a Delight” (video, Gospel Library); “God’s Greatest Creation” (Gospel Library); Old Testament Stories, “The Creation of the Earth” (8–12). Review Bible Dictionary, “Genesis”; For the Strength of Youth, “Your body is sacred” (22–29); Liahona and For the Strength of Youth magazines. Sing “All Creatures of Our God and King” (Hymns, no. 62); consult Topics, “Environmental Stewardship and Conservation.”
